name: hyksos-invasion-of-egypt
description: Semitic peoples from Western Asia conquered Lower Egypt, establishing the 15th Dynasty and introducing horse-drawn chariots to Egyptian warfare.

name: pompey-conquers-jerusalem
description: Roman general Pompey captured Jerusalem during the Third Mithridatic War, ending the Hasmonean Kingdom's independence and bringing Judea under Roman control.

name: roman-conquest-of-britain
description: Emperor Claudius launched the successful Roman invasion of Britain, establishing the province of Britannia that would last nearly four centuries.

name: clovis-defeats-visigoths-at-vouille
description: Frankish King Clovis I defeated the Visigoths, killing King Alaric II and driving the Visigoths from most of Gaul into Hispania.

name: battle-of-badr
description: The first major military victory for Muslims, where Prophet Muhammad's forces defeated a larger Meccan army, marking a turning point in early Islamic history.

name: conquest-of-mecca
description: Prophet Muhammad led 10,000 followers to capture Mecca largely without bloodshed, converting the Kaaba into Islam's holiest site.

name: battle-of-yarmouk
description: Arab Muslim forces decisively defeated the Byzantine Empire, leading to the loss of the Levant and opening the path for Islamic expansion.

name: arab-conquest-of-egypt
description: Amr ibn al-As led Arab forces to conquer Byzantine Egypt, ending over 900 years of Greco-Roman rule and beginning the Islamization of the region.

name: umayyad-conquest-of-spain
description: Tariq ibn Ziyad led Umayyad forces across Gibraltar and defeated the Visigoths, beginning nearly 800 years of Islamic presence in Iberia.

name: battle-of-talas
description: Abbasid and Tibetan forces defeated Tang China in Central Asia. Captured Chinese papermakers helped spread papermaking technology westward.

name: alfred-the-great-recaptures-london
description: King Alfred of Wessex recaptured London from the Vikings, restoring the city and strengthening Anglo-Saxon resistance to Danish invasion.

name: fourth-crusade-called
description: Pope Innocent III called for a new crusade to recapture Jerusalem, which infamously diverted to sack Constantinople in 1204 instead.

name: sixth-crusade-treaty
description: Emperor Frederick II negotiated the Treaty of Jaffa with Sultan al-Kamil, peacefully recovering Jerusalem for Christians without major combat.

name: siege-of-montsegur
description: French crusaders besieged the Cathar stronghold for ten months. Over 200 Cathars were burned at the stake after surrendering.

name: jacquerie-peasant-revolt
description: French peasants rose up against the nobility during the Hundred Years' War, attacking castles and manors before being brutally suppressed.

name: battle-of-varna
description: Ottoman forces defeated a crusading army led by King Władysław III of Poland, who was killed in battle, ending the Crusade of Varna.

name: edward-iv-crowned
description: Edward of York became King of England after defeating Lancastrian forces at Towton, the bloodiest battle in English history during the Wars of the Roses.

name: german-peasants-war-begins
description: Peasants across German-speaking lands rose up demanding economic and religious reforms. The revolt was crushed with over 100,000 peasants killed.

name: st-bartholomews-day-massacre
description: Catholic mobs massacred thousands of Huguenots across France in coordinated attacks beginning in Paris, escalating the French Wars of Religion.

name: grotius-publishes-on-the-law-of-war-and-peace
friendly_name: Grotius Publishes On the Law of War and Peace
description: Dutch jurist Hugo Grotius published his foundational work on international law, establishing principles for just war and the laws governing armed conflict.

name: irish-rebellion-of-1641
description: Irish Catholics rose against English and Scottish Protestant settlers, leading to widespread violence and eventually Cromwell's brutal conquest of Ireland.

name: franco-dutch-war-begins
description: Louis XIV invaded the Dutch Republic in the Year of Disaster. The Dutch flooded their lands and formed alliances to resist French expansion.

name: king-philips-war
description: Native American leader Metacom (King Philip) led an alliance against New England colonists in one of the bloodiest conflicts per capita in American history.

name: siege-of-derry
description: Protestant defenders held the city of Derry for 105 days against Jacobite forces loyal to the deposed Catholic King James II.

name: battle-of-the-boyne
description: William III of Orange defeated the deposed James II in Ireland, securing Protestant rule in Britain and becoming a symbol of Ulster Protestant identity.

name: war-of-spanish-succession-begins
description: European powers went to war over the Spanish throne after Charles II died without an heir, reshaping the balance of power for decades.

name: nadir-shah-sacks-delhi
description: Persian ruler Nadir Shah invaded Mughal India and plundered Delhi, taking the Peacock Throne and Koh-i-Noor diamond among vast treasures.

name: war-of-jenkins-ear
description: Britain declared war on Spain after Captain Jenkins displayed his severed ear in Parliament, claiming Spanish coastguards had cut it off.

name: war-of-austrian-succession-begins
description: European powers challenged Maria Theresa's right to inherit Habsburg lands, sparking a continent-wide war that lasted eight years.

name: battles-of-lexington-and-concord
description: The first military engagements of the American Revolution, where colonial militiamen fired the 'shot heard round the world' against British troops.

name: shays-rebellion
description: Massachusetts farmers led by Daniel Shays rebelled against debt collection and taxation, highlighting weaknesses in the Articles of Confederation.

name: irish-rebellion-of-1798
description: Irish republicans inspired by the French Revolution rose against British rule. The failed uprising led to the Act of Union with Britain.

name: war-of-1812-begins
description: The United States declared war on Britain over maritime disputes and expansionist aims, leading to the burning of Washington and the writing of the Star-Spangled Banner.

name: peterloo-massacre
description: British cavalry charged a crowd of 60,000 peaceful reformers in Manchester demanding parliamentary representation, killing 15 and injuring hundreds.

name: battle-of-ayacucho
description: South American independence forces decisively defeated Spanish royalists in Peru, effectively ending Spanish colonial rule on the continent.

name: battle-of-navarino
description: British, French, and Russian fleets destroyed the Ottoman-Egyptian fleet in Greece, the last major naval battle fought entirely with sailing ships.

name: nat-turners-rebellion
description: Enslaved preacher Nat Turner led a violent uprising in Virginia, killing about 60 white people before being captured and executed.

name: sepoy-mutiny
description: Indian soldiers rebelled against the British East India Company, triggering a widespread uprising that led to direct British Crown rule over India.

name: sand-creek-massacre
description: Colorado militia attacked a peaceful Cheyenne and Arapaho encampment, killing over 150 Native Americans, mostly women, children, and elderly.

name: nez-perce-war
description: Chief Joseph led the Nez Perce on a 1,170-mile fighting retreat toward Canada before surrendering with his famous speech 'I will fight no more forever.'

name: war-of-the-pacific
description: Chile fought Bolivia and Peru over nitrate-rich territories, winning coastal lands that left Bolivia landlocked to this day.

name: first-boer-war
description: Boer settlers defeated British forces in South Africa, winning independence for the Transvaal Republic after the Battle of Majuba Hill.

name: assassination-of-alexander-ii
description: Russian Tsar Alexander II, the 'Liberator' who freed the serfs, was killed by a bomb thrown by revolutionary terrorists in St. Petersburg.

name: assassination-of-garfield
description: President James Garfield was shot by a disappointed office-seeker, leading to civil service reform and the Pendleton Act.

name: jack-the-ripper-murders
description: An unidentified serial killer murdered at least five women in London's Whitechapel district, becoming history's most infamous unsolved case.

name: wounded-knee-massacre
description: US Army troops killed approximately 300 Lakota Sioux at Wounded Knee, South Dakota, marking the end of the American Indian Wars.

name: first-sino-japanese-war
description: Japan defeated Qing China over influence in Korea, gaining Taiwan and establishing itself as a major East Asian power.

name: philippine-american-war
description: Filipino independence fighters battled American forces after the US acquired the Philippines from Spain, resulting in hundreds of thousands of Filipino deaths.

name: assassination-of-mckinley
description: President William McKinley was shot by anarchist Leon Czolgosz at the Pan-American Exposition, making Theodore Roosevelt president.

name: end-of-philippine-american-war
description: The US declared victory in the Philippine-American War, though guerrilla resistance continued for years in parts of the archipelago.

name: kishinev-pogrom
description: A violent anti-Jewish riot in Kishinev, Russia killed 49 Jews and destroyed hundreds of homes, sparking international outrage and increased Jewish emigration.

name: herero-genocide
description: German colonial forces systematically killed tens of thousands of Herero and Nama people in German South-West Africa, considered the first genocide of the 20th century.

name: potemkin-mutiny
description: Sailors on the Russian battleship Potemkin mutinied during the 1905 Revolution, later immortalized in Eisenstein's influential 1925 film.

name: first-balkan-war
description: The Balkan League of Serbia, Greece, Bulgaria, and Montenegro attacked the Ottoman Empire, driving it out of most of its European territories.

name: second-balkan-war
description: Former allies turned on Bulgaria over disputed Macedonian territory, resulting in Bulgaria's defeat and increased tensions leading to World War I.

name: archduke-franz-ferdinand-assassinated
description: Serbian nationalist Gavrilo Princip shot the Austro-Hungarian heir in Sarajevo, triggering the chain of events that started World War I.

name: first-battle-of-the-marne
description: French and British forces halted the German advance on Paris, ending hopes for a quick victory and beginning four years of trench warfare.

name: armenian-genocide-begins
description: Ottoman authorities began the systematic deportation and massacre of Armenians, killing an estimated 1.5 million people by 1923.

name: second-battle-of-ypres-first-gas-attack
friendly_name: Second Battle of Ypres (First Gas Attack)
description: Germany deployed chlorine gas against Allied troops in Belgium, the first large-scale use of chemical weapons in modern warfare.

name: us-enters-world-war-i
description: The United States declared war on Germany after unrestricted submarine warfare and the Zimmermann Telegram, tipping the balance toward Allied victory.

name: third-afghan-war
description: Afghanistan invaded British India, leading to a brief war that resulted in full Afghan independence from British influence.

name: polish-soviet-war
description: Poland defeated the Soviet Red Army at the Battle of Warsaw, halting communist expansion into Europe and securing Polish independence.

name: turkish-war-of-independence
description: Mustafa Kemal Ataturk led Turkish nationalists to defeat Greek and Allied forces, establishing the modern Republic of Turkey.

name: invasion-of-poland
description: Nazi Germany invaded Poland on September 1st, prompting Britain and France to declare war and beginning World War II in Europe.

name: katyn-massacre
description: Soviet secret police executed approximately 22,000 Polish military officers, police, and intellectuals in the Katyn Forest and other sites.

name: trotsky-assassinated
description: Soviet agent Ramon Mercader killed exiled revolutionary Leon Trotsky in Mexico with an ice axe on Stalin's orders.

name: battle-of-the-philippine-sea
description: US Navy destroyed Japanese naval aviation in the 'Great Marianas Turkey Shoot,' securing air superiority in the Pacific War.

name: dresden-bombing
description: Allied firebombing of Dresden killed approximately 25,000 people and destroyed the historic city center, becoming one of WWII's most controversial attacks.

name: french-indochina-war-begins
description: Ho Chi Minh's Viet Minh began armed resistance against French colonial rule, starting an eight-year war that ended with French defeat at Dien Bien Phu.

name: first-arab-israeli-war
description: Arab states invaded the newly declared State of Israel, which successfully defended itself and expanded its territory beyond the UN partition plan.

name: tibet-invasion
description: The People's Republic of China invaded Tibet, defeating the small Tibetan army and incorporating Tibet into the PRC.

name: cia-coup-in-iran
description: The CIA and MI6 orchestrated a coup that overthrew democratically elected Prime Minister Mosaddegh, restoring Shah Pahlavi to power.

name: east-german-uprising
description: Workers in East Berlin and across East Germany rose up against the communist government before Soviet tanks crushed the rebellion.

name: algerian-war-begins
description: The FLN launched attacks against French rule in Algeria, beginning a brutal eight-year war that ended with Algerian independence in 1962.

name: cia-coup-in-guatemala
description: The CIA overthrew democratically elected President Arbenz to protect United Fruit Company interests, beginning decades of military rule and civil war.

name: great-leap-forward
description: Mao launched a radical campaign to rapidly industrialize China, resulting in history's deadliest famine with an estimated 30-45 million deaths.

name: sharpeville-massacre
description: South African police killed 69 Black protesters demonstrating against pass laws, galvanizing international opposition to apartheid.

name: south-vietnam-coup
description: South Vietnamese generals overthrew and assassinated President Ngo Dinh Diem with tacit US approval, destabilizing the country during the Vietnam War.

name: malcolm-x-assassinated
description: Black nationalist leader Malcolm X was shot dead in New York by members of the Nation of Islam, from which he had recently split.

name: che-guevara-killed
description: Revolutionary Che Guevara was captured and executed by Bolivian forces with CIA assistance while trying to foment revolution in South America.

name: rfk-assassinated
description: Senator Robert F. Kennedy was shot by Sirhan Sirhan in Los Angeles moments after winning the California Democratic primary.

name: tlatelolco-massacre
description: Mexican security forces killed hundreds of student protesters in Mexico City's Tlatelolco plaza, ten days before the 1968 Olympics.

name: indo-pakistani-war-1971
description: India intervened in East Pakistan's independence struggle, defeating Pakistan in two weeks and enabling the creation of Bangladesh.

name: chilean-coup
description: General Pinochet overthrew elected socialist President Salvador Allende with US support, beginning 17 years of military dictatorship.

name: soweto-uprising
description: Black South African students protested mandatory Afrikaans instruction. Police killed hundreds, including 12-year-old Hector Pieterson.

name: iran-hostage-crisis
description: Iranian revolutionaries seized the US Embassy in Tehran, holding 52 Americans hostage for 444 days and contributing to Carter's election defeat.

name: john-lennon-killed
description: Former Beatle John Lennon was shot dead outside his New York apartment by Mark David Chapman, who remains imprisoned.

name: assassination-attempt-on-reagan
description: John Hinckley Jr. shot President Reagan outside a Washington hotel, seriously wounding him. Reagan recovered and served two full terms.

name: assassination-attempt-on-pope
description: Turkish gunman Mehmet Ali Agca shot Pope John Paul II in St. Peter's Square. The Pope survived and later forgave his would-be assassin.

name: lebanon-war-1982
description: Israel invaded Lebanon to expel the PLO, beginning an 18-year occupation of southern Lebanon and reshaping Middle Eastern politics.

name: sabra-and-shatila-massacre
description: Lebanese Christian militiamen massacred hundreds to thousands of Palestinians in Beirut refugee camps while Israeli forces surrounded the area.

name: korean-air-lines-007-shot-down
description: Soviet fighters shot down a Korean passenger jet that strayed into Soviet airspace, killing all 269 aboard and escalating Cold War tensions.

name: beirut-barracks-bombing
description: Truck bombs killed 241 US Marines and 58 French paratroopers in Beirut, the deadliest single attack on US Marines since Iwo Jima.

name: assassination-of-indira-gandhi
description: Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was shot by her Sikh bodyguards in retaliation for ordering the assault on the Golden Temple.

name: iran-iraq-war-ends
description: The devastating eight-year war between Iran and Iraq ended in a ceasefire with no territorial changes and over one million dead.

name: panama-invasion
description: US forces invaded Panama to depose dictator Manuel Noriega on drug trafficking charges, the largest American military operation since Vietnam.

name: siege-of-sarajevo-begins
description: Bosnian Serb forces began the longest siege in modern warfare history, lasting nearly four years and killing over 11,000 Sarajevo residents.

name: la-riots
description: Los Angeles erupted in deadly riots after police officers were acquitted of beating Rodney King, causing over $1 billion in damage.

name: us-embassy-bombings
description: Al-Qaeda bombed US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, killing 224 people and marking a major escalation in jihadist attacks on America.

name: bali-bombings
description: Jemaah Islamiyah terrorists bombed nightclubs in Bali, killing 202 people, mostly Australian tourists, in Indonesia's deadliest terror attack.

name: moscow-theatre-hostage-crisis
description: Chechen militants seized a Moscow theater with 850 hostages. Russian special forces used gas in the rescue, killing 130 hostages.

name: darfur-genocide-begins
description: Sudanese government forces and Janjaweed militias began systematic attacks on non-Arab populations in Darfur, killing an estimated 300,000 people.

name: norway-attacks
description: Far-right terrorist Anders Breivik bombed Oslo and massacred 69 people at a youth camp, Norway's deadliest peacetime attack.

name: boston-marathon-bombing
description: Brothers Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev detonated bombs near the Boston Marathon finish line, killing 3 and injuring over 260.

name: charlie-hebdo-attack
description: Islamist gunmen killed 12 people at the French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo, sparking global 'Je Suis Charlie' solidarity.

name: san-bernardino-attack
description: A married couple killed 14 people at a San Bernardino holiday party in an ISIS-inspired attack, one of the deadliest US terror attacks since 9/11.

name: nice-truck-attack
description: A terrorist drove a truck through Bastille Day crowds on Nice's Promenade des Anglais, killing 86 people in an ISIS-claimed attack.

name: khashoggi-murder
description: Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi was murdered and dismembered inside the Saudi consulate in Istanbul by a team linked to Crown Prince MBS.

name: nagorno-karabakh-war-2020
description: Azerbaijan recaptured most of Nagorno-Karabakh from Armenian forces in a 44-day war featuring extensive drone warfare.

name: sudan-civil-war-2023
description: Fighting erupted between Sudan's army and the Rapid Support Forces paramilitary, causing massive displacement and humanitarian crisis.
